questions.questionText: Given that the frequency ranges for visible light, X-rays, and gamma rays are $!$4.0 \times 10^{14}$!$ Hz to $!$8.0 \times 10^{14}$!$ Hz, $!$3.0 \times 10^{16}$!$ Hz to $!$3.0 \times 10^{19}$!$ Hz, and $!$3.0 \times 10^{19}$!$ Hz to $!$3.0 \times 10^{23}$!$ Hz respectively, calculate the ratio of the maximum frequency of a gamma ray to the maximum frequency of an X-ray, which represents how many times greater the maximum energy of a gamma ray is compared to that of an X-ray.

steps.stepText: Let's start by identifying which arithmetic operation you should use to compute the ratio of the maximum frequencies. Which operation would correctly compare the gamma ray maximum frequency to the X-ray maximum frequency?

Now, use the provided maximum frequency values of $!$3.0 \times 10^{23}$!$ Hz for gamma rays and $!$3.0 \times 10^{19}$!$ Hz for X-rays to calculate the ratio by applying the operation you identified. What numerical value do you obtain for this ratio?

Finally, based on the relationship between frequency and energy in electromagnetic waves, decide what this ratio implies about the energy of a gamma ray compared to an X-ray. Which statement best reflects the implication of your calculated ratio?

options.optionText: Gamma rays have approximately 10,000 times higher energy than X-rays.
Gamma rays have approximately 10,000 times lower energy than X-rays.
Gamma rays and X-rays have nearly the same energy.
Gamma rays have only about twice the energy of X-rays.

questions.questionText: An air traffic controller relies on a radar system that emits pulses of microwaves to track aircraft. These electromagnetic waves travel at the speed of light. The engineers ensure precise frequency and wavelength, understanding that a higher frequency results in a shorter wavelength, crucial for detailed target resolution according to the wave equation. If the radar system emits microwaves with a wavelength of $!$0.03 \text{ m}$!$ and receives the reflected pulse from an aircraft $!$0.0001 \text{ s}$!$ after emission, calculate the distance of the aircraft from the radar. Assume the speed of electromagnetic waves in air is $!$3 \times 10^8 \text{ m/s}$!$.

steps.stepText: Let's start by analyzing the time measurement. The time provided is for the pulse's round-trip journey (to the aircraft and back). To determine the time taken for a one-way trip, divide the total time by 2. Please calculate the one-way travel time.
Great, now that you've computed the one-way travel time, recall the basic distance relation used in these situations. Which of the following formulas correctly relates distance, speed, and time?
Now, use the one-way time and the given speed of electromagnetic waves to calculate the one-way distance to the aircraft. Multiply the speed by the one-way travel time to arrive at the distance.
